docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: Federal health insurance subsidies start to expire, hotels get creative with loyalty perks and other consumer-focused items from today's Times.
docs.snippet: Federal health insurance subsidies start to expire, hotels get creative with loyalty perks and other consumer-focused items from today's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama heads to West Point on Tuesday, where he will speak about the next steps in the war in Afghanistan.
docs.abstract: The president will address the nation from West Point about his plan for Afghanistan on Tuesday.
docs.snippet: The president will address the nation from West Point about his plan for Afghanistan on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Franklin D. Roosevelt’s argument that public programs can make private ones deliver applies to the current push for a public option for health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate opened debate on major health care legislation Monday, including the first two amendments in what is expected to be a weeks-long blizzard of proposed changes to the bill. Under an agreement between Democrats and Republicans, each side was allowed one amendment Monday, with votes to be held perhaps on Tuesday afternoon.
docs.abstract: Senate opens debate on major health care legislation, including first two amendments in what is expected to be weeks-long blizzard of proposed changes; Sen Barbara Mikulski proposes enhanced screenings and other preventive care for women at low or no cost to patients; Sen John McCain offers proposal to remove provisions aimed at slowing rise in government spending on Medicare (S)
docs.snippet: The Senate opened debate on major health care legislation Monday, including the first two amendments in what is expected to be a weeks-long blizzard of proposed changes to the bill.      Under an agreement between Democrats and Republicans, each side...

docs.lead_paragraph: The changes the health care bills in Congress envision are years away -- not soon enough to help the millions of unemployed people who on Monday lost their temporary federal subsidies for health insurance. That means that people like Linda Rasor, 56, who lives in Haslett, Mich., and was laid off from her energy consulting job in February, will have to start paying three times as much for health insurance.
docs.abstract: Millions of unemployed people, who lost their jobs from September 2008 to this December, are about to lose temporary federal subsidies, approved under economic stimulus package, of Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act, popularly known as Cobra (S)
docs.snippet: The changes the health care bills in Congress envision are years away -- not soon enough to help the millions of unemployed people who on Monday lost their temporary federal subsidies for health insurance.      That means that people like Linda...

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers of the Prescriptions blog had plenty to say on Monday after the Congressional Budget Office released its analysis of the impact that health care legislation would have on insurance premiums in 2016. It found that for most people -- those with employer coverage -- the impact would be minimal, although some people might see costs rise. Here is a sampling of the reader comments: ''Good to have the report in. Maybe it will give some of those on the fence cover to support the bill.'' -- Susan, Western Washington
docs.abstract: Sampling of reader comments about Prescriptions blog after Congressional Budget Office released its analysis of impact that health care legislation would have on insurance premiums in 2016 (S)
